title: Elwood HW1
description: HW1 using the COVID 19 Italy Response survey.
contents:
# HomeworkOneTemplate.r
# This tells us what this file does
#
# Curtis Atkisson 7.9.2021

# Reminder: the # "comments" out a line of text; that is, if you precede a line with "#",
# then R ignores that line

# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
# front end material.
# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

library(tidyverse)

# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
# Some quick code reminders
# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

# Here's an example of storing an object.
hello <- paste("Hello World!")

# Look over there ->
# In the "Environment" window, you'll see that you've created an object that is
# now stored in your workspace.

# Now type hello. R "pastes" the line of text that says "Hello World!" as your output.

# Ok, with those reminders out of the way, let's get some data into R

# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
# Reading in Data
# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

# What you need to do from here on out is dependent on the dataset
# you choose to work with! Here's an example of how I'd approach this with
# a file using "+" as a delimiter

myData <- read_tsv("../../_data/covid-responses.tab")

# let's unpack that a bit.
# I'm creating an object called myData
# I'm using the read.delim() function to read it in
# I'm specifying the name of the file; it's in my working directory!
# I'm specifying the delimiter (here, "+", but often commas (",") or tabs ("\t")
# I'm specifying that there is a header included in the data that features the variable names
# Don't forget to look at the data import samples code to get examples of other ways to import data.

# Now, let's check the first few rows. I'll let you remember how to do that!
head(myData)

# How many columns are there in the dataset?

# What are the column names?

# Should any of these columns have gather() or spread() applied to them to make them more
# useful? If so, perform those operations. If you want a challenge, try to use
# pivot_longer() or pivot_wider() instead.
print("The gather function is useful when variables are spread across columns. In this dataset
      it seems that each column represents a unique variable, and so gathering is unnecessary.
      Similarly, the spread function is useful when observations are split across multiple rows
      and you want to organize them under a single column. In this dataset each row represents
      a unique observation, so spreading is unnecessary.")


[1] "The gather function is useful when variables are spread across columns. In this dataset\n      it seems that each column represents a unique variable, and so gathering is unnecessary.\n      Similarly, the spread function is useful when observations are split across multiple rows\n      and you want to organize them under a single column. In this dataset each row represents\n      a unique observation, so spreading is unnecessary."

# I printed every column for the first 10 rows to get a better grasp of the whole dataset:
options(tibble.width = Inf)
# print(myData)

# Do one operation that requires creating a new object and doing something to that object

# There is a block of the survey called "Perception of policies, anxiety" from columns
# "percievedreaction" to "Q26". If we wanted to focus in on this block for whatever reason, 
# we could use select() to make a new dataset with only those columns.

perPolAnx <- select(myData, perceivedreaction:Q26)
print(perPolAnx)

# ... with 3,450 more rows

# Do one thing to some portion of these data that hasn't been covered so far in the course materials. Be creative and have fun!

# The survey asks respondents to react on a scale of 1 to 5. In this dataset those responses
# are stored as strings ranging from Strongly Distrust to Strongly Trust. If we want to perform
# numeric operations on these responses (such as finding the mean) we have to convert them back
# to numeric form using mutate() and recode(). Here this is done for Q36:

perPolAnx <- mutate(perPolAnx, Q36N = recode(Q36, "Strongly distrust" = 1, "Distrust" = 2, "Neither trust nor
                                 distrust" = 3, "Somewhat trust" = 4, "Strongly trust" = 5))
#print(perPolAnx)

# Now we can find the mean:
summarize(perPolAnx, Q36mean = mean(Q36N, na.rm = TRUE))


# A tibble: 1 x 1
  Q36mean
    <dbl>
1    3.40

title: Elwood HW 1
description: Homework 1 using the COVID Response in Italy Survey Data.
contents:
# HomeworkOneTemplate.r
# This tells us what this file does
#
# Curtis Atkisson 7.9.2021

# Reminder: the # "comments" out a line of text; that is, if you precede a line with "#",
# then R ignores that line

# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
# front end material.
# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

library(tidyverse)

# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
# Some quick code reminders
# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

# Here's an example of storing an object.
hello <- paste("Hello World!")

# Look over there ->
# In the "Environment" window, you'll see that you've created an object that is
# now stored in your workspace.

# Now type hello. R "pastes" the line of text that says "Hello World!" as your output.

# Ok, with those reminders out of the way, let's get some data into R

# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
# Reading in Data
# =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

# What you need to do from here on out is dependent on the dataset
# you choose to work with! Here's an example of how I'd approach this with
# a file using "+" as a delimiter
wd <- getwd()
setwd("..")
setwd("..")
myData <- read_tsv("_data/covid-responses.tab")
setwd(wd)

# let's unpack that a bit.
# I'm creating an object called myData
# I'm using the read.delim() function to read it in
# I'm specifying the name of the file; it's in my working directory!
# I'm specifying the delimiter (here, "+", but often commas (",") or tabs ("\t")
# I'm specifying that there is a header included in the data that features the variable names
# Don't forget to look at the data import samples code to get examples of other ways to import data.

# Now, let's check the first few rows. I'll let you remember how to do that!
head(myData)

# useful? If so, perform those operations. If you want a challenge, try to use
# pivot_longer() or pivot_wider() instead.
print("The gather function is useful when variables are spread across columns. In this dataset
      it seems that each column represents a unique variable, and so gathering is unnecessary.
      Similarly, the spread function is useful when observations are split across multiple rows
      and you want to organize them under a single column. In this dataset each row represents
      a unique observation, so spreading is unnecessary.")

# "percievedreaction" to "Q26". If we wanted to focus in on this block for whatever reason, 
# we could use select() to make a new dataset with only those columns.

perPolAnx <- select(myData, perceivedreaction:Q26)
print(perPolAnx)

# ... with 3,450 more rows

# Do one thing to some portion of these data that hasn't been covered so far in the course materials. Be creative and have fun!

# The survey asks respondents to react on a scale of 1 to 5. In this dataset those responses
# are stored as strings ranging from Strongly Distrust to Strongly Trust. If we want to perform
# numeric operations on these responses (such as finding the mean) we have to convert them back
# to numeric form using mutate() and recode(). Here this is done for Q36:

perPolAnx <- mutate(perPolAnx, Q36N = recode(Q36, "Strongly distrust" = 1, "Distrust" = 2, "Neither trust nor
                                 distrust" = 3, "Somewhat trust" = 4, "Strongly trust" = 5))
#print(perPolAnx)

# Now we can find the mean:
summarize(perPolAnx, Q36mean = mean(Q36N, na.rm = TRUE))


# A tibble: 1 x 1
  Q36mean
    <dbl>
1    3.40

title: Homework One Resubmission
description: My Homework One no longer shows on GitHub, so here's a resubmit.
contents:
The data I am using was provided by The Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project. I happened to be slacking off from practicing R, when in the middle of an article (posted on theintercept.com, if Im not mistaken) the above mentioned project was referenced. The dataset I chose to use is entitled Disorder Involving the Media. It contains data on political violence and demonstrations involving journalists and media workers.
#First I am going to load the data, which you will not see since I used the include=FALSE option in my first chunk of code.
#Next, I am going to preview the first few rows of the data using the head() function.

# A tibble: 6 x 29
    ISO EVENT_ID_CNTY EVENT_ID_NO_CNTY EVENT_DATE           YEAR
  <dbl> <chr>                    <dbl> <dttm>              <dbl>
1     0 XKX35                       35 2018-04-20 00:00:00  2018
2     0 XKX38                       38 2018-05-03 00:00:00  2018
3     0 XKX52                       52 2018-06-12 00:00:00  2018
4     0 XKX86                       86 2018-09-09 00:00:00  2018
5     0 XKX167                     167 2019-01-28 00:00:00  2019
6     0 XKX260                     260 2019-08-23 00:00:00  2019
  TIME_PRECISION EVENT_TYPE                 SUB_EVENT_TYPE  
           <dbl> <chr>                      <chr>           
1              2 Violence against civilians Attack          
2              1 Protests                   Peaceful protest
3              1 Violence against civilians Attack          
4              1 Violence against civilians Attack          
5              1 Protests                   Peaceful protest
6              1 Violence against civilians Attack          
  ACTOR1                            ASSOC_ACTOR_1                  
  <chr>                             <chr>                          
1 Unidentified Armed Group (Kosovo) Albanian Ethnic Group (Kosovo) 
2 Protesters (Kosovo)               Journalists (Kosovo)

  INTER1 ACTOR2

  ASSOC_ACTOR_2                                       INTER2
  <chr>                                                <dbl>

2 <NA>                                                     0

6 Journalists (Kosovo)                                     7
  INTERACTION REGION COUNTRY ADMIN1    ADMIN2          ADMIN3
        <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr>     <chr>           <chr> 
1          37 Europe Kosovo  Mitrovica North Mitrovica <NA>

2 On May 3, 2018, on the occasion of the World Press Freedom Day, in ~

  FATALITIES  TIMESTAMP
       <dbl>      <dbl>
1          0 1572403786
2          0 1574110420
3          0 1553853272
4          0 1572403700
5          0 1572403627
6          0 1567533545

Hmm, cant seem to glean much from that well come back to select specific variables in a bit. For now, lets see how many rows and columns are in this dataset. I can do this with the ncol() and nrow() functions. Doing this, I see that there are 29 columns and 12460 rows in the journalist.data dataset. What you dont see in the last sentence is that my row and column amounts were calculated within backstrokes (these little guys ``, not to be confused with these guys . See chapter 27.2 in the R for Data Science textbook for this trick).
#Let me give you the column names from my dataset.

 [1] "ISO"              "EVENT_ID_CNTY"    "EVENT_ID_NO_CNTY"
 [4] "EVENT_DATE"       "YEAR"             "TIME_PRECISION"  
 [7] "EVENT_TYPE"       "SUB_EVENT_TYPE"   "ACTOR1"          
[10] "ASSOC_ACTOR_1"    "INTER1"           "ACTOR2"          
[13] "ASSOC_ACTOR_2"    "INTER2"           "INTERACTION"     
[16] "REGION"           "COUNTRY"          "ADMIN1"          
[19] "ADMIN2"           "ADMIN3"           "LOCATION"        
[22] "LATITUDE"         "LONGITUDE"        "GEO_PRECISION"   
[25] "SOURCE"           "SOURCE_SCALE"     "NOTES"           
[28] "FATALITIES"       "TIMESTAMP"       

#As far as my untrained eye can see, there is no need for the gather() or spread() function in the dataset. Each variable has its own column, each observation its own row, and each value has its own cell. Great job ACLED, very professional!
#Take a look at the following columns of data:

# A tibble: 12,460 x 2
   EVENT_DATE          TIME_PRECISION
   <dttm>                       <dbl>
 1 2018-04-20 00:00:00              2
 2 2018-05-03 00:00:00              1
 3 2018-06-12 00:00:00              1
 4 2018-09-09 00:00:00              1
 5 2019-01-28 00:00:00              1
 6 2019-08-23 00:00:00              1
 7 2019-12-17 00:00:00              1
 8 2020-03-23 00:00:00              1
 9 2020-04-11 00:00:00              1
10 2020-12-22 00:00:00              1
# ... with 12,450 more rows

Looking through the codebook for the data I can see that the TIME_PRECISION column refers to the precision of the time an event occurred in the previous column EVENT_DATE. A code of 1 indicates the event happened on a specific day, a code of 2 indicates the even happened sometime during a specified week, and a code of 3 sometime during a specified month. I am going to recode these numbers to correspond to text. Ill include the code as a reference to what I did.


journalist.data <- mutate(journalist.data, certaintyOfDate= recode(TIME_PRECISION, `1`= "dayOf", `2`= "weekOf", `3`= "monthOf")) 
head(select(journalist.data, certaintyOfDate, EVENT_DATE))


# A tibble: 6 x 2
  certaintyOfDate EVENT_DATE         
  <chr>           <dttm>             
1 weekOf          2018-04-20 00:00:00
2 dayOf           2018-05-03 00:00:00
3 dayOf           2018-06-12 00:00:00
4 dayOf           2018-09-09 00:00:00
5 dayOf           2019-01-28 00:00:00
6 dayOf           2019-08-23 00:00:00

And there you have it! You can now see Ive recoded the TIME_PRECISION column to certaintyOfDate. Ive also included the EVENT_DATE column so you can see what the TIME_PRECISION column is referring to.
###Now for the be creative and have fun part. Ill include the code so yalls can see. I spent some time in the forums trying to get the barchart on the up and up. Enjoy!


eventType <- table(journalist.data$EVENT_TYPE)

eventType



                   Battles Explosions/Remote violence 
                        10                        246 
                  Protests                      Riots 
                      7713                       1666 
    Strategic developments Violence against civilians 
                       400                       2425 

par(mar=c(12,4,1,1))
      
barplot(eventType, main="Event Type Occurance Since January 2020", ylim=c(0, 8000), xlab= "", las= 2, cex.names=1)

mtext(text="Event Type", side = 1, line=5)

title: Homework 6 Chris Elwood
description: An introduction and a few lines of R.
contents:
Hi! My name is Chris and Im a senior undergraduate at UMass majoring in Philosophy with a minor in Computer Science. Im taking this course as an elective because Im certain data analysis and data science will continue to revolutionize the way humans understand the world in the 21st century and beyond, and Im curious to learn as much as I can. Im originally from Concord, Massachusetts and also lived in New York City for a long period of time.
Heres a few simple lines of R, its thrilling stuff:


2+2


[1] 4

5*5


[1] 25

prime_numbers <- c(2,3,5,7,11,13,17)
prime_numbers


[1]  2  3  5  7 11 13 17

double_prime_numbers <- prime_numbers * 2
double_prime_numbers


[1]  4  6 10 14 22 26 34

double_prime_numbers > prime_numbers


[1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE

Learn more about using Distill at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

Incremental improvement over time!

title: NathanCoyotePostResubmission
description: Repost of Homework 6 containing 5 lines of code.
contents:
lets see if this works
only one way to find out
yessir
#this is a comment only, but if I space after the # symbol it becomes a header
this is a comment only, but if I space after the # symbol it becomes a header, like so!

[1] 2 4 6 8

title: Jessica Intro
description: Hello, my name is Jessica Fuller. I am 24 years old and am from Rochester, MA. I am a huge animal lover and have 3 cats and 2 dogs. I'm also an avid sports fan and enjoying working out and staying active. I am pursuing my master's degree in data analytics because I hope to enter the data science field, and I would like to expand my programming and analytics skills.

title: Enare
contents:
Introduction to Class
Hello everyone! My name is Alphoncina (Allie) and Im a master of public policy and administration student here at UMass. Im interested in ways that data and data science can be used to facilitate policy making and informing policymakers.
Statistical Analysis in R

title: Introduction
contents:
I have two cats lying on me as I write this.
One is named Lana, and she is calm and chill.
One is named Murphy, and he is a tornado.
To have both cats sleeping and keeping my legs warm is the motivation I needed to keep pushing to understand this tonight.
This mix of motivation and being goofy and tired led me to have some fun writing code that visualizes a cow quoting random Wikipedia facts:

title: Welcome to DACSS 601
description:
Welcome to DACSS 601: Foundations of Data Science. We hope you enjoy 
reading what we have to say!
contents: Hey, everyone! Were gonna have fun!
